text.p: Cable and Wireless Communications Plc, the proposed merger between the British units of four cable companies, on Monday detailed the terms of the the planned merger and flotation.
The offer document sets out the terms under which investors in NYNEX CableComms and Bell CableMedia (BCM) will be able to switch into C&WC shares.
Under the terms of the offer each Bell Cablemedia share would receieve 0.69389 C&WC ordinary shares.
The offer for Nynex CableComms unit is 0.36746 C&WC ordinary shares.
C&WC said in a statement that it has received irrevocable undertakings of 65 percent to accept the BCM offer and of 67 percent to accept the NYNEX CableComms offers.
C&WC is the planned merger company between Mercury Communications, the UK unit of Cable and Wireless Plc, BCM, Videotron and NYNEX.

C&WC said its pro forma revenues for the year ended March 31, 1996, were 1.9 billion stg with net income of 44 million stg. For the nine months to December 31, 1996, revenues were 1.5 billion with net income of 93 million.
The planned merger, which was announced last October, will make C&WC Britain's biggest cable group.

"I see tremendous opportunities in bringing together Mercury's telecommunications expertise, particularly in the business sector, with NYNEX CableComms' and Bell Cablemedia's direct access to the consumer, providing telephony and cable TV entertainment," said Graham Wallace, chief executive of C&WC.
